name: Path
description: Path utilities for working with URLs and file paths in a cross-platform way. All paths that are passed in will become normalized to have posix separators. ```js import { path } from 'pixi.js'; path.normalize('http://www.example.com/foo/bar/../baz'); // http://www.example.com/foo/baz ```

properties.name: toPosix
properties.description: Converts a path to posix format.

properties.name: isUrl
properties.description: Checks if the path is a URL e.g. http://, https://

properties.name: isDataUrl
properties.description: Checks if the path is a data URL

properties.name: isBlobUrl
properties.description: Checks if the path is a blob URL

properties.name: hasProtocol
properties.description: Checks if the path has a protocol e.g. http://, https://, file:///, data:, blob:, C:/ This will return true for windows file paths

properties.name: getProtocol
properties.description: Returns the protocol of the path e.g. http://, https://, file:///, data:, blob:, C:/

properties.name: toAbsolute
properties.type: (url: string, baseUrl?: string, rootUrl?: string) => string
properties.description: Converts URL to an absolute path. When loading from a Web Worker, we must use absolute paths. If the URL is already absolute we return it as is If it's not, we convert it

properties.name: normalize
properties.description: Normalizes the given path, resolving '..' and '.' segments

properties.name: isAbsolute
properties.description: Determines if path is an absolute path. Absolute paths can be urls, data urls, or paths on disk

properties.name: join
properties.description: Joins all given path segments together using the platform-specific separator as a delimiter, then normalizes the resulting path

properties.name: dirname
properties.description: Returns the directory name of a path

properties.name: rootname
properties.description: Returns the root of the path e.g. /, C:/, file:///, http://domain.com/

properties.name: basename
properties.description: Returns the last portion of a path

properties.name: extname
properties.description: Returns the extension of the path, from the last occurrence of the . (period) character to end of string in the last portion of the path. If there is no . in the last portion of the path, or if there are no . characters other than the first character of the basename of path, an empty string is returned.

properties.name: parse
properties.type: (path: string) => { root?: string, dir?: string, base?: string, ext?: string, name?: string }
properties.description: Parses a path into an object containing the 'root', `dir`, `base`, `ext`, and `name` properties.

properties.name: sep
properties.type:
string,
    delimiter: string,
    joinExtensions: string[],
}

/**
 * Path utilities for working with URLs and file paths in a cross-platform way.
 * All paths that are passed in will become normalized to have posix separators.
 * @example
 * ```ts
 * import { path } from 'pixi.js'

properties.name: http
properties.type:
//example.com/assets/images/texture.png'
 * ```
 * @remarks
 * - Normalizes to POSIX separators (forward slashes)
 * - Handles URLs, data URLs, and file paths
 * - Supports path composition and decomposition
 * - Common in asset loading and URL management
 * @category utils
 * @standard
 * @see {@link Path} For full API reference
 * @see {@link DOMAdapter} For platform-specific path handling
 */
